statement.p: A shift cipher is one in which the letters of the alphabet have been shifted by some fixed amount.
The classic example is the so-called Caesar Cipher which shifts the alphabet to the right three letters. A becomes D, B becomes E, etc.
We encrypt letter-by-letter via the function e(x) = x + 3 \pmod{26} and decrypt via d(x) = x-3 \pmod{26}.
Decrypt the following message: L FDQ DOZDBV WUXVM BRX, EUXWXV.
An affine cipher is one in which letters are transformed via a linear function, e(x) = ax+b \pmod{n} where a, b\in \Z and n\in \Z^+. If a =0, this is a shift cipher.

note.p: To be able to decrypt an affine function, we need \gcd(a,n)=1 in order that a is an invertible element. We can find the inverse via the Euclidean Algorithm with back-substitution. Recall, the inverse of an invertible element is its Bezout coefficient.

statement.p:

subsection.title: Number Theory Using Sage
subsection.p:
Sage has a convenient way of determining if a number is prime by asking if the number is in a set primes:
37 in Primes()
True
Try testing any number in the cell above.

If you want to just want to get a prime number of some particular size (as we want with our RSA activity), we ask sage for the next_prime:
next_prime(123456)
123457

The following Sage code allows us to find the GCD and Bezout coefficients via the xgcd command:
# Change a and b to be any positive integers, then press Evaluate a=2345 b = 234 l = a.xgcd(b) pretty_print(str(l[0]) + "=" + str(a) + "*(" + str(l[1]) + ") + " + str(b) + "*(" + str(l[2]) + ")")
1=2345*(47) + 234*(-471)
The xgcd command returns a list of the form (gcd, first Bezout coefficient, second Bezout coefficient), and the code above pretty-prints this in a readable format.

In order to do modular exponentiation, we use the powermod function. For example, to compute 2019^{2019} \pmod{1000}:
2019.powermod(2019,1000)
979

import re, string, math
from itertools import izip_longest
def grouper(iterable, n, fillvalue=None): args = [iter(iterable)] * n return izip_longest(*args, fillvalue=fillvalue)
def encrypt(): stripped_string = re.sub(r"\W|\d","", m.strip()).upper()
int_string = "" for i in range(0,len(stripped_string)): the_int = string.ascii_uppercase.index(stripped_string[i]) if the_int < 10: int_string += "0" + str(the_int) else: int_string += str(the_int)
half_num_digits = (ceil(math.log10(n))//2) block_size = (half_num_digits-1)*2 if (int(half_num_digits*"25") > n) else half_num_digits*2
# append the string with x's to fill the block size. if (len(int_string) % block_size > 0): int_string += "23"*((block_size-(len(int_string) % block_size))//2)
# Chunk the message into block_size chunks; a list of string representations blocks = [("".join(x)) for x in grouper(int_string, block_size)]
cipher_blocks = [] for block in blocks: cipher_blocks.append(pow(long(block), e, n))

plain_blocks = [] for block in c: plain_block = pow(long(block), d, n) plain_blocks.append(("0"*(block_size - len(str(plain_block))))+ str(plain_block))
plaintext_message="".join(plain_blocks)
message = "" ind = 0 while ind < len(plaintext_message): message += string.ascii_uppercase[ int(plaintext_message[ind:ind+2]) ] ind += 2 print(message)
